author: By Giulia Heyward
title: Sonny Perdue Is Sole Finalist to Lead Georgia’s Public Universities
description: The Board of Regents announced that the former Republican governor is its choice to become chancellor. His selection has angered professors concerned about academic freedom.
content: Georgia’s public university system said on Tuesday that former Gov. Sonny Perdue was its sole finalist to become chancellor, a choice that has outraged some professors and led a regional agency to threaten the accreditation of the 26-school system.

title: U.S. prime-time broadcast coverage includes medal events in Alpine skiing and women’s hockey.

content: The U.S. broadcast coverage of the 2022 Winter Games continues on Wednesday with medal events in Alpine skiing and women’s hockey, as curling continues. All times are Eastern.

author: By Matt Stevens
title: 5 Monologues, Each a Showcase for Asian American Actors Over 60
description: “Out of Time” at the Public Theater is intended to showcase the talents of older actors. “People want to dismiss your stories,” the show’s director says. Not here.

title: ‘Alcarràs’ Wins Top Prize at Berlin Film Festival

content: BERLIN — The top prize at the Berlin International Film Festival, the Golden Bear for best feature film, was given on Wednesday to “Alcarràs,” a contemplative work about peach farmers in a village in northern Spain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: San Francisco Ousts School Board Members
description: Amid frustrations about remote learning and changes to admissions for an elite high school, parents — led by Asian Americans — kicked out three board members.
content: Today: San Francisco voters oust school board members. A sexual harassment case at Harvard exposes the messy realities of Title IX complaints. And, some pretty on-the-nose life advice from a kindergartner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: How Jonathan Larson Taught Me to Become a Better Critic
description: In the film version of “Tick, Tick … Boom!,” about a composer who dreams of Broadway, a “Rent” die-hard discovers more to love in musical theater.
content: I watched “Tick, Tick … Boom!,” Netflix’s film adaptation of the Jonathan Larson musical, four and a half times in the span of three weeks. I’ve listened to the soundtrack three times, with the exception of the opening song, “30/90.” That I’ve listened to at least a dozen times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: In Landslide, San Francisco Forces Out 3 Board of Education Members
description: The recall, which galvanized Asian Americans, was a victory for parents angered by the district’s priorities during the pandemic.
content: In a recall election fueled by pandemic angst and anger, San Francisco voters ousted three members of the Board of Education on Tuesday, closing a bitter chapter in the city’s politics that was rife with infighting, accusations of racism and a flurry of lawsuits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ortved
title: Yes, There Were Fashion Week Parties
description: Rodarte, Diesel and Shayne Oliver held parties on Friday night.
content: Is it really New York Fashion Week? Many designers sat this one out and, for a moment, the party calendar looked pretty bleak. Luckily, the invitations began trickling in late last week. Here are some highlights from Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Tosiello
title: ‘Law & Order’ Is Having an Identity Crisis
description: The franchise has always portrayed the police as flawed but ultimately good. The latest spinoff does away with that ambivalence.
content: If you were going to watch a police procedural — which, for the record, I don’t particularly recommend — you could do worse than NBC’s “Law & Order” franchise. Across 32 years and more than 1,200 episodes, the original series and its six American spinoffs have offered a gentle critique of law enforcement, presenting a parade of flawed individuals navigating a byzantine justice system. Detectives are stymied by bureaucrats and squabble with lunkhead patrol officers, who reliably contaminate crime scenes. Idealistic prosecutors grow disillusioned and leave for nonprofit work. And yet the franchise still hinges on a lesser-of-two-evils logic: The institutions may be imperfect, and the cops imperfect, but their vocation is, by definition, good. There are always more victims to avenge, and none better equipped to do it than the New York Police Department.
source.name: The New York Times

content: WASHINGTON — Ryan Zinke, the former interior secretary, misused his position and lied to investigators about his involvement in a Montana land deal, repeatedly breaking federal ethics rules, a government watchdog said on Wednesday.

title: Executives Are Quitting to Spend Time With Family … Really
description: At the highest levels of corporate America, top executives are reassessing the role of work in their lives, stepping back and walking away.
content: Some were burned out. Some were unhappy. Some were disillusioned. Some wanted their lives back. Some truly and genuinely wanted to spend more time with their families. All, in their own ways, decided that they’d had enough with the intense demands that come with being a senior executive, and walked away.

title: Covid Patients May Have Increased Risk of Developing Mental Health Problems
description: A new, large study found that in the year after getting Covid, people were significantly more likely to be diagnosed with psychiatric disorders they hadn’t had than people who didn’t get infected.
content: Social isolation, economic stress, loss of loved ones and other struggles during the pandemic have contributed to rising mental health issues like anxiety and depression.

title: Japan’s Unions ‘Are Built Around Men.’ Can a Female Leader Change That?
description: To attract working women, the once-mighty Japanese labor movement must prove it can be a strong ally on issues like child care and sexual harassment.
content: TOKYO — Women have never found a welcoming home in Japan’s labor unions. Sexism is entrenched. Problems like wage discrimination and sexual harassment at work are often ignored. Many women, lacking a voice, have given up on the movement.

author: By Ali Watkins
title: What Daniel Nigro Has Seen in a Half-Century of Firefighting
description: The retiring Fire Department commissioner discusses how the department, and even the fires it fights, have changed over the decades.
content: Across Daniel A. Nigro’s 73 years, there’s been one constant: the New York City Fire Department. He followed his father into the ranks in 1969, and in the 53 years since, Mr. Nigro held almost every job there is to hold in the department, from “probie” at a Manhattan engine house to fire commissioner.

title: Regulators are looking into whether short sellers improperly influenced stock prices.
description: Prominent short sellers including Carson Block and Andrew Left are said to have received search warrants as part of an ongoing investigation into possible manipulation of stock prices.
content: Some Wall Street investors have made a profession out of exposing companies with shoddy or even fraudulent operations while betting that their share prices will fall. title: Jurors in the Sarah Palin trial said they knew of the judge’s decision to dismiss before their verdict.
description: The judge said several jurors acknowledged knowing about his decision but said it had not “played any role whatever in their deliberations.”
content: Several jurors in the defamation case brought by Sarah Palin against The New York Times said they found out about the judge’s decision to dismiss the case while they were still deliberating, the judge, Jed S. Rakoff, said in an order on Wednesday.

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: Afghans Who Bet on Fast Path to the U.S. Are Facing a Closed Door
description: Only a handful of applications for entry on urgent humanitarian grounds have been processed, and most have been denied.
content: LOS ANGELES — As a combat interpreter in Afghanistan, Sharif Azizi helped U.S. Special Forces hunt down Taliban targets, even after suffering leg and chest injuries from stepping on a land mine. title: For his last Olympics, the skier Gus Kenworthy is competing for Britain.
description: A dual citizen, Kenworthy was born in Britain and grew up in Telluride, Colo. He skied for the United States at the 2014 and 2018 Games.
content: He has competed in the Winter Games twice before, but this year will look different for the freestyle skier Gus Kenworthy. He has a new team and a new Olympic event: halfpipe skiing.

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: How Are You Feeling About Returning to the Office? We Want to Hear About It.
description: Tell us what you’re worried or excited about as you prepare to potentially leave remote work behind.
content: Remote work has been a source of relief for some people. Going to the office often meant pressure to arrive early and stay late. It might have brought a steady stream of microaggressions. Even the most extroverted could find water cooler banter wearying. In numerous studies conducted last year, researchers found that a majority of women and people of color preferred working from home for a range of reasons. But plenty of employees have also missed the camaraderie and mentorship of in-person work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan
title: Chicken and Potatoes With Commanding Flavor
description: Country Captain is a Southern classic with roots in the British Empire. This Anglo-Indian version is simple yet luxurious.
content: The American South has long laid claim to Country Captain. As found on tables from Charleston to Savannah, it’s a dish of chicken crisped then simmered with half-​melted tomatoes and curry powder. It comes with toppings, decorous or wanton, as you wish: almonds and grated coconut for crunch, sweet-sour currants, nubs of bacon like a strafe of salt. The constant is a bed of Carolina rice, each grain fluffed and preening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Prevost
title: House Hunting in Canada: Seclusion in the Forests of British Columbia

content: This cedar-shingled three-bedroom home occupies nearly six acres on the southern shore of Quadra Island, which sits between Vancouver Island and the Pacific coastline of British Columbia, Canada. The wooded waterfront property, completed in 2004, includes a three-bedroom guest cabin and a jetty with a dock large enough to accommodate a 45-foot boat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Sokol
title: In Orlando, 25 Mysterious Basquiats Come Under the Magnifying Glass
description: Vibrant paintings on cardboard said to be by the artist were found in the storage unit of a Hollywood screenwriter. Will a museum show resolve questions about their authenticity — or raise new ones?
content: It seems like a story too good to be true, and for some in the art world, it is. Last weekend, 25 Jean-Michel Basquiat paintings were publicly unveiled at the Orlando Museum of Art before several thousand V.I.P.s. All of the paintings were said by the museum to have been created in late 1982 while Basquiat, 22, was living and working out of a studio space beneath Larry Gagosian’s home in Venice, Calif., preparing fresh canvases for a show at the art dealer’s Los Angeles gallery.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Democrats Weigh Gas Tax Holiday and Deficit Cuts as Inflation Mounts

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir and Natalie Kitroeff
title: Behind the Fractious Collaboration Steering the Canada Protests
description: The organizers include former law enforcement officers, military veterans and conservative organizers who are steering unrest that has sent shock waves throughout Canada.
content: OTTAWA — Since the big rigs entrenched in the core of Canada’s capital first pulled in nearly three weeks ago, they have arranged themselves in a semblance of order, parking in evenly spaced rows. Their drivers have stayed warm and are fed by a corps of marshaled volunteers, and though they have varying personal beliefs, they appear carefully on-message: “Freedom!” has been the repeated refrain for the past 19 days.
source.name: The New York Times

title: On the Edge of a Polish Forest, Where Some of Putin’s Darkest Fears Lurk
description: A U.S. missile facility in Poland is at the heart of an issue animating the Kremlin’s calculations over whether to go to war against Ukraine.
content: REDZIKOWO, Poland — Tomasz Czescik, a Polish archaeologist and television journalist, walks his dog each morning through a forest near his home here on NATO’s eastern flank, wandering along the edge of a green chain-link fence topped with razor wire.

author: By Jessica Grose
title: When the Parenting Never Stops
description: A new book focuses on “difficult adult children,” offspring who need complex help into their later lives.
content: We have a mainstream directive for raising children in our society: You provide them with support, shelter and care until they’re 18, and then they’re supposed to be, more or less, self-sufficient, launched into the world as adults. This framework leaves out millions of parents whose children struggle with substance abuse or mental illness, who may be providing active care to their adult children for the rest of their lives.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Congressional Democrats Ask Biden to Review Treatment of Black Migrants

It’s by far the grandest building on this Ninth Arrondissement block — and thus an unexpected home for Saint-Lazare, a product and design firm best known for its utilitarian aesthetic and stylish use of humble materials.

title: Two young athletes, two very different outcomes in an Olympic doping scandal.

description: Mr. O’Rourke’s remarks during his 2020 presidential campaign shadow him in the Texas governor’s race, complicating his attempt to pull off a Democratic upset.
content: TYLER, Texas — Even in deep red East Texas, even on a Tuesday afternoon, even after a failed bid for the Senate followed by a failed bid for president, Beto O’Rourke still draws a crowd.

author: By Amanda Fortini
title: The Ceramists Ushering in a New Era of Surrealism
description: These makers are finding beauty and strangeness in the everyday, producing winking renderings of prawns, ashtrays and more.
content: IN HIS 1869 poetic novel, “Les Chants de Maldoror,” the French writer Isidore Lucien Ducasse, known pseudonymously as the Comte de Lautréamont, describes a young boy who is as “beautiful as the chance encounter of a sewing machine and an umbrella on an operating table.” Lautréamont’s book was rediscovered and championed by the Surrealists after World War I, and this particular simile became a kind of foundational mantra for the movement. Its juxtaposition of mundane objects in an unexpected setting conveyed the Surrealists’ cheekiness, their love of the incongruous and irrational and their overriding fascination with found curiosities.

title: Eric Adams Proposes a $98 Billion Budget With No Cuts for N.Y.P.D.
description: The mayor’s first budget proposal called for across-the-board cuts to most city agencies, as well as a reduction in the city’s work force.
content: Mayor Eric Adams, who rode a tough-on-crime platform to victory in November, has spent his first few weeks in office being buffeted by a spate of violent crimes in New York City, including the killing of two police officers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Taking Aim at Environmental Racism, Without Mentioning Race
description: President Biden says he wants to alleviate the outsize burdens that Americans of color face from pollution. But using race to allocate help could mean legal trouble.
content: Before we get to the news this week, we wanted to tell you about some changes we’re making to the Climate Fwd: newsletter — changes meant to help make sense of the climate crisis and what it means for you. Starting next month, Climate Fwd: will be delivered twice a week instead of once. And, Somini Sengupta, the Times’s global climate correspondent, will be your new guide to the latest news and ideas as the newsletter’s lead writer. Please stay tuned for more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Biden warns a Ukraine invasion is still possible.
content: President Biden said yesterday at the White House that a Russian invasion of Ukraine “remains distinctly possible,” but he vowed to give diplomacy “every chance.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Beverly Ross, Teenage Songwriter in Rock ’n’ Roll’s Youth, Dies at 87
description: With hits like “Lollipop,” she became a top woman songwriter in the early 1960s, but she quit the business in frustration over the theft of her work.
content: Beverly Ross, who with hits like “Lollipop” became one of the top women songwriters in rock ’n’ roll’s early years, but who ended her career early after a work relationship turned sour, died on Jan. 15 in a hospital in Nashville. She was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Troubled London Police Force Searches for a New Leader
description: The change at the top comes at an awkward moment for the Metropolitan Police Service: It is investigating the government for breaking lockdown rules and faces scrutiny for its own scandals.
content: LONDON — London’s police department was already dealing with a crisis of trust amid allegations of misogyny, racism and bullying when it became embroiled in a political drama. Last month, it opened an investigation into parties at Downing Street during lockdown that could determine Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s political fate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Steel, Jodi Kantor, Michael M. Grynbaum, James B. Stewart and John Koblin
title: How a Secret Assault Allegation Against an Anchor Upended CNN and Jeff Zucker
description: The network’s top-rated host and its president were forced out following ethical lapses, an office romance and a letter from a lawyer for “Jane Doe.”
content: Late in the day on Nov. 30, Jeff Zucker, the president of CNN Worldwide, summoned his star anchor and friend, Chris Cuomo, to a meeting in the network’s skyscraper overlooking the Hudson River.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Casey Schwartz
title: It’s Time We Reclaim Our Focus
description: In his new book, Johann Hari investigates how our brains have been broken by technology — and what we can do to fight back.
content: The typical American worker focuses on a given task for just three minutes. Each day, we touch or check our phones more than 2,000 times, and spend more than three hours staring at them, on average. So says Johann Hari, an author who has previously written about depression and addiction, in his new book “Stolen Focus.” It is an investigation into how we got ourselves into this distracted state — what Mr. Hari describes as an “attention crisis.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin and Michael M. Grynbaum
title: CNN’s parent cites journalistic lapses in Jeff Zucker’s exit, as another executive resigns.
description: Allison Gollust, who led marketing at the network, had remained in her job after she and Mr. Zucker, the former president of CNN, acknowledged a romantic relationship.
content: CNN’s parent company said on Tuesday that journalistic lapses had contributed to the sudden exit of Jeff Zucker, who resigned as the network’s president this month after acknowledging a romantic affair with a fellow executive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Retail Sales Jumped in January, Another Sign of the Economy’s Resilience
description: The 3.8 percent gain followed a 2.5 percent drop in December.
content: Prices were rising fast, products were in short supply and the Omicron variant put a chill on the country at the start of the year. Through it all, American consumers kept spending.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa and Richard Fausset
title: Prosecutors Focus on Arbery Killers’ Failure to Help as He Lay Dying
description: The men were previously convicted of murder. The government is now trying to build a case that racism fueled their actions.
content: BRUNSWICK, Ga. — Prosecutors in the hate crimes trial of Ahmaud Arbery’s pursuers on Tuesday focused on showing the ways in which the government believes that the defendants’ racism manifested itself on the day Mr. Arbery was murdered — including the fact that they did not try to help him as he lay dying in the street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: ignominious
description: This word has appeared in 27 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word ignominious has appeared in 27 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 11 in “Hochul Vows a Change in Tone as the Cuomo Era Nears an End in Albany” by Luis Ferré-Sadurní:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: An Olympic tussle over a snowboard logo roils the Games for a U.S. athlete.
description: The word Prada across the bottom of Julia Marino’s snowboard ran afoul of competition regulations, but only after her silver medal in slopestyle.
content: It wasn’t just Julia Marino’s silver medal performance in the slopestyle event that grabbed attention in Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Afro-Colombian Dancing Reawakens the Joyce Theater
description: Sankofa Danazfro returns to New York with “Accommodating Lie,” a curiously muted work about the display of Black Bodies
content: The motion is small, a little twisting in the hips. But like a tremor before an earthquake, it signals larger shifts. Soon, drums kick in and dancers explode into percussive action — shaking, undulating, whacking the air with the force of those drums.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Review: A ‘Merchant of Venice’ That Doubles Down on Pain
description: John Douglas Thompson stars in Arin Arbus’s caustic and assertive new production of the Shakespeare play.
content: More than 30 years ago, John Douglas Thompson, then a successful salesman at a Fortune 500 company, saw a play in New Haven, Conn. When it was over, he offered up a prayer: “Please, God, make me an actor. Teach me how to do that, and make this possible for me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir and Dan Bilefsky
title: An activist who has advocated secession by western provinces becomes the public face of the Canada protests.
description: Tamara Lich, an Alberta activist, has channeled the truckers’ grievances, raised money and deployed social media to become a leading voice among the protesters.
content: She is a former fitness instructor who has sung and played guitar in a band called “Blind Monday” in Medicine Hat, Alberta. She was a senior member of a splinter party that advocated for Canada’s Western provinces to secede from the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt
title: Biden Rejects Trump’s Claim of Privilege for White House Visitor Logs
description: The president informed the National Archives that it should turn over the logs sought by the Jan. 6 committee within 15 days.
content: President Biden ordered the National Archives to hand over a range of visitor logs from the Trump White House to the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, rejecting his predecessor’s claim that the material is protected by executive privilege.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: British inflation climbs to 5.5 percent, highest in 30 years.
description: The higher-than-expected reading has increased speculation that the Bank of England could raise rates again as soon as next month.
content: Inflation in Britain accelerated in January, with prices increasing at their fastest pace in three decades, adding to concerns about a painful squeeze on household budgets a day after separate data showed wage growth wasn’t keeping up with prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris
title: ‘Taste’ Review: A Slow, Sensual Hallucination Set in Vietnam
description: The first feature film from the director Le Bao is a spare series of handsome tableaux that ultimately feels undercooked.
content: I won’t bother explaining what “Taste” is about. It’s more dreamed up than a term like “about” can capture. The movie is all tableaux — pacific, surveillant, surreal. Three naked women ride a motorbike around a tiny room. Those same women arrange a boxy television set on a top bunk while, in an adjoining room, a man pumps himself into a fourth woman. The women drag that man (he’s naked, too) from one room to the next, careful not to wake him as he sleeps with his arms around a swordfish as long as he is. A scene later, the five of them are hacking the fish up, cleaning it, for the meal we later see them eat. Later on: karaoke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ionova
title: Mudslides in Brazil Kill at Least 94 People
description: Intense rainfall caused mudslides and flooding that destroyed part of the city of Petrópolis, in a region where a similar disaster in 2011 killed more than 900.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — Firefighters and desperate residents searched for victims Wednesday after powerful mudslides and flooding swept through a mountainous region north of Rio de Janeiro, dumping a month’s worth of rain overnight and killing at least 94 people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Eleven Years After the Sandy Hook Massacre, a $73 Million Settlement
description: The deal with Remington, which made the rifle used in the attack, appears to be the largest involving a gun manufacturer and relatives of victims.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at settlements in two high-profile lawsuits — one filed against the company that manufactured that AR-15-style rifle used in the Sandy Hook school massacre in Connecticut 11 years ago, the other filed against Prince Andrew by a teenage victim of his friend, Jeffrey Epstein.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: ‘CODA’ Star Troy Kotsur on His Historic, Healing Oscar Nomination
description: The deaf actor endured years of rejection and financial struggle. “I was so used to failure that I didn’t realize I would surpass even my own expectations.”
content: It has only been a week since Troy Kotsur became the first deaf man to earn an Oscar nomination for acting, but to the 53-year-old performer, it already feels like the start of something new.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Mariah Kreutter
title: Russia, Winter Olympics, Fashion Week: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Nope to Metamates, Googlers and Puritans
description: It’s time for tech employees to outgrow their cutesy names. Please.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: The Myth of the Magic Sports Beard
description: The Super Bowl hero Cooper Kupp is just the latest star athlete with unruly facial hair to see his performance explode.
content: So you were not crazy about the Super Bowl hero Cooper Kupp’s scraggly, mountain-man whiskers? Neither is his family, apparently.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: Defiant Ottawa Protesters Brace for a Clampdown
description: The response of law enforcement in the nation’s capital has been painfully sluggish for many residents. But police signaled they may finally be ready to move in.
content: The police on Wednesday ordered protesters clogging Ottawa’s streets to leave or face criminal charges, appearing to set the stage for a clampdown aimed at ending demonstrations that have roiled the nation’s capital for weeks, and reverberated around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez and Yubelka Mendoza
title: Hugo Torres, Former Rebel Turned Political Prisoner, Dies at 73
description: Once a guerrilla commander who helped free President Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua from prison, Mr. Torres was jailed last year during a political crackdown.
content: Hugo Torres, a former guerrilla leader who helped spring Nicaraguan president Daniel Ortega out of jail, only to be imprisoned by Mr. Ortega himself last year, died on Friday at a hospital in Managua. He was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward
title: A new Virginia law will end school mask mandates and limit remote instruction.
description: The law gives parents the right to exempt their children from mask-wearing without stating a reason. It also requires a full academic year of in-person instruction.
content: After weeks of back-and-forth, Gov. Glenn Youngkin of Virginia, a Republican, signed into law on Wednesday a bill that will effectively bar mask mandates in schools, by giving parents the right to exempt their children from mask-wearing without stating a reason.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Ken Kurson, Kushner Ally Pardoned by Trump, Takes Plea Deal
description: Mr. Kurson, a former newspaper editor, was accused of cyberstalking his former wife both before and after their 2016 divorce.
content: Ken Kurson, a former editor of The New York Observer who was charged with unlawfully spying on his former wife, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to two misdemeanors, with the opportunity to have the charges further reduced after a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: He Could Barely Walk, and He Was Seeing Double. What Was Wrong?
description: Could he be having a stroke — or was it something more unusual?
content: “OK, I give up,” said the 74-year-old man. “I’ll go to the hospital.” His wife of 46 years gave an inner sigh of relief. Her husband was stubborn, a seventh-​generation Mainer, not given to complaining. But a few weeks earlier, she noticed that he was parking his tractor next to the back porch so he could get on it without pulling himself up. Then he needed help getting out of his big chair. Now he could barely walk. It happened so suddenly it scared her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Are Your Tomatoes ‘Epic’? If Not, Here’s What You Should Be Doing
description: Tomato experts Craig LeHoullier and Joe Lamp’l have some advice for you.
content: “We are the luckiest tomato growers in all of history,” proclaimed Craig LeHoullier as he thumbed with dramatic effect through the Seed Savers Exchange yearbook, a hefty index of nearly 12,000 heirloom varieties of the beloved Solanum lycopersicum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Publishing C.E.O. Donates $500,000 to Fight Book Bans
description: Markus Dohle, the chief executive of Penguin Random House, said the effort “ties into the future of our democracy.”
content: Markus Dohle, the chief executive of Penguin Random House, will personally donate at least $500,000 to the free-speech organization PEN America in an effort to combat book banning in the United States, PEN announced on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Victim’s Rape Kit Was Used to Identify Her as a Suspect in Another Case
description: San Francisco’s district attorney said victims were “being treated like criminals,” and called for legislators to ban the practice. His office dropped charges in her case.
content: The San Francisco police are using DNA samples collected from sexual assault victims to identify them as possible suspects in other crimes, the city’s district attorney said this week, adding that he would encourage legislation to ban the practice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Private Equity Investor Sentenced to 15 Months in College Bribery Case
description: Prosecutors said John Wilson, 62, of Lynnfield, Mass., paid more than $1.2 million to ensure that his three children would be admitted to elite universities as purported Division I athletic recruits.
content: A private equity investor who paid more than $1.2 million to secure the admission of his three children to elite universities as purported athletic recruits was sentenced on Wednesday to 15 months in prison, the longest sentence yet in the nationwide college admissions bribery case, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Google Plans Privacy Changes, but Promises to Not Be Disruptive
description: It says it will give other companies plenty of time to adapt to changes to its Android software. Similar changes made by Apple affected big internet companies.
content: Google said on Wednesday that it was working on privacy measures meant to limit the sharing of data on smartphones running its Android software. But the company promised those changes would not be as disruptive as a similar move by Apple last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: The Education Department will wipe out loans for students defrauded by DeVry University.
description: It’s the first such move involving a for-profit chain that’s still in business.
content: The Education Department will cancel federal student loans for at least 1,800 students who attended DeVry University, once one of the nation’s largest for-profit college chains, because it fraudulently lured in applicants for years with vastly inflated claims about their career prospects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Group Chat
description: Are your group texts a “social lifeline” for you? Have they changed over the course of the pandemic?
content: Are you in any group chats via text? What role do group chats play in your life? When are they great? When are they annoying?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Irma Thomas, a Soul Queen Far Beyond New Orleans
description: As she turns 81, the singer whose intimacy matches her grandeur is the subject of a PBS documentary, “Irma: My Life in Music.”
content: The singer Irma Thomas has long been known as the Soul Queen of New Orleans, a title that feels both richly deserved and far too provincial. Her songs never topped the Billboard pop chart, but they did climb it. And even today, they’re covered by bar bands and in blues jams across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: Hong Kong’s Scary Surge
description: The city is in the thick of its worst wave yet, and is facing a dangerous dilemma.
content: Hong Kong is in the thick of its worst wave yet and is facing a dangerous dilemma: It can’t live with the virus, but can’t stop it, either.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: How Long Will Los Angeles Have a Mask Mandate?
description: Barbara Ferrer, the county’s top public health official, talks about what a future with Covid-19 looks like.
content: For almost two years, as the coronavirus has surged and receded and surged again in Los Angeles, Barbara Ferrer, the county’s public health director, has been a steady voice of caution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: After Sexual Harassment Lawsuit, Critics Attack Harvard’s Release of Therapy Records
description: The very act of making a sexual harassment claim can set off a convoluted legal procedure unfamiliar to accusers. Experts say the university has both legal and ethical considerations.
content: In 2020, after Lilia Kilburn, a graduate student, filed a formal complaint notifying Harvard University that an anthropology professor was sexually harassing her, an investigation was opened, as required by federal law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins
title: Texas sues to strike down the federal mask mandate for air travelers.
description: The state’s attorney general said the mandate was unconstitutional, even though the Supreme Court recently declined to hear a similar case.
content: The Republican attorney general of Texas on Wednesday sued to strike down the Biden administration’s mandate requiring travelers to wear masks at airports, on airplanes and on commuter bus and rail systems.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Mitski, in and Out of the Spotlight
description: The indie-rock musician’s albums inspire deep feelings and attract ever-bigger audiences, but in many ways she remains a mystery.
content: “Laurel Hell,” the new album by the beloved indie-rock singer-songwriter Mitski, continues her shift toward a focus on pop — a move that feels somewhat at odds with the general reluctance she displays in almost every other aspect of being a performer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Are You a Risk-Taker?
description: Do you enjoy being adventurous, or do extreme feats frighten you?
content: The athletes at the Winter Olympics in Beijing are competing in some of the world’s most dangerous sports on some of the most unforgiving terrain: Snowboarders fling themselves off a 22-foot halfpipe, alpine skiers race down a mountain at 90 miles per hour, luge athletes fly down a track made of ice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Is Sleepy Joe Biden Making Vladimir Putin Blink?
description: Biden has given Putin reason to think through his plans further.
content: The Ukraine story is far from over. But if Vladimir Putin opts to back away from invading Ukraine, even temporarily, it’s because Joe Biden — that guy whose right-wing critics suggest is so deep in dementia he wouldn’t know Kyiv from Kansas or AARP from NATO — has matched every Putin chess move with an effective counter of his own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘For Lucio’ Review: The Voice of Italy for Four Decades
description: A new documentary pays tribute to Lucio Dalla, a popular and passionate Italian singer whose songs captured the country’s political turmoil.
content: Pudgy and hirsute, favoring floppy hats and round glasses, Lucio Dalla didn’t look much like a pop star. A jazz clarinetist who reinvented himself as a singer-songwriter, Dalla nonetheless became one of Italy’s most beloved troubadours in the later decades of the 20th century. His songs were rhapsodic and discursive, polemical and observant — often within the span of a single verse — and his voice could shift from conversational intimacy to full-throated passion just as quickly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: Six Highlights From the Black Film Archive
description: Maya Cade, who founded the archive in August 2021, discusses a film she loves from each decade from the 1920s through the 1970s.
content: Next week, the Black Film Archive — a living register of Black cinema — will officially turn six months old. Its roots, though, stretch back much farther, to the time its founder, Maya Cade, was studying journalism at Howard University. There, she edited the arts section of the student newspaper, The Hilltop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: I Dug Into Whether Sanctions Will Work Against Russia
description: Can economic penalties deter Russia from invading Ukraine?
content: There are two clashing arguments about whether the threat of economic sanctions can be effective now in deterring Russian aggression in Ukraine. One is that sanctions against Russia following the 2014 invasion of Ukraine didn’t prompt any improvement in behavior, nor did sanctions promote good behavior when imposed against Cuba, Iran, Iraq, North Korea and Venezuela. So it’s unrealistic to expect sterner sanctions to work against Russia this time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Canaan and North Canaan, Conn.: Once Sleepy, Now Awakening
description: The Litchfield County towns used to be considered too remote by many second-home buyers. But thanks to the pandemic — and remote work — that’s changed.
content: After pulling off a notable second act of reinvention, the Canaans, in Litchfield County, Conn., may be on the verge of a third.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Mamoudou Athie Gets Switched On by TV on the Radio and ‘Cowboy Bebop’
description: The actor reveals his feelings about his new Netflix series, “Archive 81,” the inspiration of David Bowie and the real reason he bought a bike.
content: Mamoudou Athie speaks unabashedly about tenderness, humanity and humility, and doing the right thing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Weekly Accessible Learning Activities: Truck Drivers, Basketball Heroes and Love
description: Each week we spotlight five student activities created for a broad range of learners based on reporting in The New York Times.
content: Each Wednesday we shine a spotlight on five student activities that support a broad range of learners. In this week’s roundup of accessible activities, we invite students to write a love poem, learn about truck drivers, watch a film about the “Queen of Basketball,” look closely at an intriguing photo and write an original story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: The Little TV Industry That Could
description: Want a medical drama, a spy thriller, a snowy neo-noir? Finland has you covered.
content: Americans who stream a lot of television are likely to have some familiarity with British or South Korean or Latin American TV. They may even have an idea of what to expect from a Turkish or Israeli or South African show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Suit Is Not So Dead After All
description: At least according to the designer Peter Do. So is New York, according to Michael Kors.
content: It was the penultimate night of New York Fashion Week, and Mayor Eric Adams was finally sitting front and center at a major fashion show, his first big one since assuming office. (Earlier in the week he stopped in to see the In the BLK presentation of three emerging Black designers created by the #ChangeFashion initiative.) The designer of choice?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: TelevisaUnivision Unveils Plans for Streaming Service in Spanish
description: It’s called ViX. A free ad-supported tier will start on March 31, and a premium subscription service will follow later this year.
content: There are nearly 600 million Spanish speakers in this world, and they have become a highly sought-after audience for streaming services. Netflix announced last year that it would spend $300 million on original Mexican productions. Disney+ said in late 2020 that it had more than 70 original Spanish-language productions in development. WarnerMedia started HBO Max in Latin America in June, announcing a commitment of 100 productions in the region in the next two years. And NBCUniversal’s Telemundo will offer Tplus this fall on Peacock’s premium tier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Gabriela Bhaskar
title: Beijing Got All Ready for Olympic Curling. But About the Ice …
description: The ice makers of Olympic curling are part physicist, part meteorologist, part engineer. They know that creating a stage for a world-class event is all about the process.
content: Follow our live coverage of the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Austin Ramzy
title: Hong Kong Can’t Live With the Virus. It Can’t Stop It, Either.
description: An Omicron surge has exposed the weaknesses of a system that was once a world leader in containing the coronavirus.
content: HONG KONG — The scenes were straight out of China’s coronavirus playbook. Armies of workers, deployed to lock down residents. Plans to erect a massive makeshift hospital. And on Wednesday, a command from Xi Jinping, the country’s top leader, plastered across local front pages: “Make controlling the epidemic as soon as possible an overwhelming priority.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Anton Troianovski and Michael D. Shear
title: Ukraine Tensions Spike as West Accuses Russia of Lying About Troop Withdrawal
description: As Russia stoked hopes of a diplomatic solution and claimed to be pulling back forces from the Ukrainian border, U.S. and NATO officials accused Moscow of building up troops instead.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Tensions over Ukraine abruptly ratcheted up on Wednesday as Western officials accused Russia of lying about whether it had really begun pulling back troops from the Ukrainian border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Dunks on Trump for Getting Dumped During Tax Season
description: “It’s like getting divorced on Christmas Eve,” Jimmy Kimmel joked.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Mikaela Shiffrin’s Alpine Career Is Far From Over
description: The skier’s setbacks in Beijing fit the historical narrative arc of many greats in the sport, including her compatriots Bode Miller, Lindsey Vonn and Ted Ligety.
content: I first saw Mikaela Shiffrin ski when she was 14 at an Eastern championship for top junior racers culled from nine states. Shiffrin beat everyone (including my daughter) by 11 seconds in a race usually decided by tenths of a second, if not hundredths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Walter Dellinger, Top Legal Official in Clinton White House, Dies at 80
description: He served as both the head of the Office of Legal Counsel and acting solicitor general, and he remained a leading figure in liberal legal battles.
content: Walter Dellinger, a renowned scholar of constitutional law and one of the top legal figures in the Clinton administration, which he served as head of the Office of Legal Counsel and later as acting solicitor general, died on Wednesday at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine McLaughlin
title: Long a Foundational Material, Concrete Is Now a Finishing Touch
description: Traditionally used industrially, concrete has become a preferred medium for those who seek austere and unusual décor.
content: Toward the end of 2019, Natalie Feltham started to look for a simple, minimal vessel for burning incense in her home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azeen Ghorayshi
title: Trans Swimmer Revives an Old Debate in Elite Sports: What Defines a Woman?
description: For nearly a century, certain elite athletes have been subject to anatomical, chromosomal or hormonal testing to compete in women’s events.
content: At the Ivy League women’s swimming championships this week, many eyes in the crowd will be fixed on Lia Thomas, a star of the University of Pennsylvania team. In recent months, Thomas has made headlines not only for her speed — handily winning one Ohio race that went viral — but also for her gender identity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: An Immersive History of Mixed-Descent Native Families
description: In “Born of Lakes and Plains,” Anne F. Hyde draws attention to the roles that intermarriage played in the development of the American West.
content: Any history of Indigenous peoples in North America must reckon with the reality of exploitation, ethnic cleansing and genocide; but to reduce their experiences to unending violence is to adopt, however unwittingly, the perspective of European settlers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Late to the Punch Line
description: Rich Proulx stitches together a vibrant puzzle.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Rarely does a Wednesday puzzle make me shake my head in wonder at how a constructor has managed to translate an interesting linguistic pattern into a crossword theme, but today’s puzzle by Rich Proulx was jaw-droppingly clever. author: By Maggie Jones
title: See (the Worst People in) the World!
description: How defiant Covid-era customers turned a dream job — flight attendant — into a total nightmare.
content: It was the German shepherd in Row 4 that finally pushed Veronica, a flight attendant, over the edge. He was Veronica’s third ‘unruly passenger,’ as the Federal Aviation Administration calls them, in one month. A week or two before the dog, a middle-aged man reacted belligerently when, just before he boarded the plane, Veronica asked him to pull up his mask. ‘Who do you think you are, you liberals?!’ he screamed at her. ‘These masks don’t work.’ Then he threatened to punch her in the face. About a week before, it was a group of young female athletes. The girls kept removing their masks when they talked to one another, and Veronica, who was working the back of the plane near the girls, repeatedly reminded them: “Please put your mask on.” (She and most other attendants asked me not to use their full names, either because an airline’s media policy does not allow them to speak without permission or for fear that doing so might hinder their employment.) “Please put your mask on,” a girl mocked Veronica each time she said it. When the girl got up to go to the bathroom, without a mask, Veronica asked again. The girl, who was about 5-foot-10 and towered over Veronica’s 5-foot-2 frame, said: “I’m so sick and tired of you, bitch. You don’t have authority over me.” They were almost body to body in the cramped area near the lavatory, and Veronica feared the girl was about to hit her, before one of the coaches intervened.
